data.summary: 2 potential security concerns detected. Review the identified risks below and consider taking preventive action.

detectedThreats.title: Approval Abuse Detected
detectedThreats.description: An approval was granted and immediately used to transfer assets. This is a common drainer pattern.

detectedThreats.title: Active Approval to Malicious Contract
detectedThreats.description: You have an active approval allowing a known malicious contract to spend your USDC tokens.

approvals.riskReason: Approved spender is a known malicious contract
Unlimited approval amount - spender can drain all tokens

suspiciousTransactions.description: An approval was granted and immediately used to transfer assets.

recommendations.title: Revoke High-Risk Token Approvals
recommendations.description: You have 2 high-risk approvals that should be revoked immediately to prevent unauthorized token transfers.

recommendations.title: Consider Moving Assets to Safe Wallet
recommendations.description: Due to the detected threats, consider transferring remaining assets to a fresh, secure wallet.

recommendations.title: Audit Recent Signature Requests
recommendations.description: Review any recent signature requests you approved. Malicious signatures can be used even without on-chain transactions.

recommendations.title: Schedule Regular Security Audits
recommendations.description: Periodically review your wallet approvals and transaction history to catch potential threats early.

steps.title: Revoke Malicious Approvals
steps.description: Revoke 1 approval to known malicious contracts. This is the highest priority.

steps.title: Revoke High-Risk Approvals
steps.description: Revoke 1 high-risk approval including unlimited token approvals.

steps.title: Transfer Assets to Safe Wallet
steps.description: Move all remaining assets to a fresh wallet that has never been used before. Do NOT reuse the seed phrase.

warnings: Never share your seed phrase or private key with anyone
Verify all transaction details before signing
Be cautious of phishing sites mimicking recovery tools

attackExplanation.whatHappened: An approval hijack occurs when a malicious actor gains the ability to spend your tokens through a token approval you granted.
attackExplanation.howItWorks: When you approve a contract to spend tokens, you give it permission to transfer tokens on your behalf. Attackers exploit this by: 1) Creating fake dApps that request approvals, 2) Phishing sites that mimic legitimate protocols, 3) Compromised legitimate protocols.
attackExplanation.ongoingDamage: The approved contract can drain your tokens at any time until the approval is revoked.
attackExplanation.recoverableInfo: Revoke the malicious approval immediately. Any tokens already stolen cannot be recovered.

preventionTips.title: Never share your seed phrase
preventionTips.description: No legitimate service will ever ask for your seed phrase. Anyone asking for it is trying to steal your funds.

preventionTips.title: Use hardware wallets for high-value assets
preventionTips.description: Hardware wallets keep your private keys offline, making them much harder to steal.

preventionTips.title: Review before signing
preventionTips.description: Always carefully review what you are signing. Use transaction simulation tools when available.

preventionTips.title: Limit token approvals
preventionTips.description: Only approve the exact amount needed, not unlimited. Regularly review and revoke old approvals.

securityChecklist.item: Use a hardware wallet for significant holdings
Backup seed phrase in secure offline location
Review and revoke unnecessary token approvals monthly
Use dedicated browser profile for crypto
Disable browser extensions when signing transactions
